meta.subject: South African Sign Language Home Language

questions.topic: Definition and discussion of how pace is used in the poem

introduction: Pace is a poetic device which is used to captivate the viewer and portray the message of the poet through movement (slow and fast).
Changes in pace may be seen in change of actions or when highlighting a particular moment in the poem.

points: At the beginning of the poem the signs are slower as the children sense the tension, distrust and indication of suspicion.
Following the shooting of the person, the man running is signed at a very slow pace to draw attention to the seriousness of the action represented.
The learner carries the dead boy in slow motion which indicates the shocking tragedy.
The learner carries the coffin in slow pace or motion which indicates the depth of emotions associated with the tragedy.
The funeral is also signed at a slower pace to show the extreme sorrow and despair.
The slow pace allows the viewer to absorb each second of emotion that the poet is experiencing.
The viewer is compelled to empathize with the emotion within the poem.
Towards the middle of the poem, the children realize that they cannot understand the language in the classroom.
They look at each other in confusion.
This shows the learners' hatred and intolerance towards the schooling system that they are forced to be part of.
Occurs when the children begin to protest and scream.
The children are throwing stones.
The sparks fly from the bombs.
The bombs are exploding.
There is chaos in the school environment/society as leaners refuse to conform to this oppressive schooling system.
As the children return to school and are studying contentedly because they overcame their struggles and accomplished their purpose.
Their message was heard and actions were taken to resolve the problem.
Freedom of choice in education was achieved.
Is indicated when the learner is shot and we witness the extreme violence of police brutality.

model_answers: Lonely
Unwanted
Depressed
Unsupported
Isolated
questions.marker_instruction: Accept any TWO of the above or similar responses.

model_answers: To emphasis the intensity of his feelings.
To gain the empathy of the viewer for the signer's state of mind.
questions.marker_instruction: Accept the above or similar responses.

questions.text: Effect of image in context of 'ALONE'
model_answers: Love can bring change in a person's emotional state.
Love brings life.
Love can come in any form or shape.
Love brings change of perspective.
questions.marker_instruction: Accept any similar response with THREE positive points.

questions.text: Elements in nature mirroring emotions in 'ALONE'
model_answers: Rain – represents emotions of sadness, depression, tears.
Wind/cold – represents emotions of loneliness, isolation, depression, being unsupported.
Sun – represents emotions of hope, new beginnings, and positive attitude.
questions.marker_instruction: Accept any similar response with THREE distinct points.

questions.text: Drawing attention to senses in 'FIVE SENSES'
model_answers: The poet uses exaggerated movements of the left hand to indicate the 5 senses.
Eye gaze is fixed on the left hand.
Right hand moves to the left to close with an exaggerated deliberate movement.
questions.marker_instruction: Accept any TWO of the above or similar responses.

model_answers: NMF shows negative feelings.
The sense is unhappy because it is unable to communicate / needs support.
questions.marker_instruction: Accept the above or other similar responses.

model_answers: The poet signs/uses BOTH to indicate the sense of hearing and the sense of sight.
He reinforces that the two senses collaborate with each other.
They work together to support each other.
They are interdependent.
questions.marker_instruction: Accept any THREE of the above or similar responses.

questions.text: Signer being Deaf reflected in 'FIVE SENSES'
model_answers: The poet taps the senses. Tapping is an acceptable action in Deaf culture.
The senses show their function instead of explaining. The visual access is better for the Deaf.
The modified 5-hand is an expression of Deaf culture / language / identity.
questions.marker_instruction: Accept the above or similar responses.

model_answers: The WORLD is created beautifully.
The WORLD is well crafted.
The earth moves in its own orbit.
questions.marker_instruction: Accept any TWO of the above or similar responses.

questions.text: Relationship between roses and animals in 'THE ROSEBUSH'
model_answers: They have an interdependent relationship.
The plants provide food for the animals and the animals provides a reproductive function for the plants.
questions.marker_instruction: Accept TWO of the above or similar responses.

model_answers: The feature is slow motion.
The specific signs are slowed down further.
The signs outside of the signing space and the pause create a crisis point in the poem.
questions.marker_instruction: Accept THREE of the above or similar responses.

questions.text: Signer's attitude towards destruction of nature in 'THE ROSEBUSH'
model_answers: The signer indicates clearly that she supports protecting nature. She signs graciously with positive NMFs.
When she signs about nature being destroyed her signing is harsh with big movements and negative NMFs.
The comment at the end of the poem that we can either cherish or destroy nature and the consequences thereof leads to the end question.
The signer pertinently and strategically poses a question at the end of her poem where she wants the viewer to make the choice to cherish or destroy.
She now leaves the viewer with something to think about.
questions.marker_instruction: Accept any THREE of the above or similar responses.

model_answers: For a Deaf child an interpreter is needed/mandatory.
There is a lot of speaking taking place which may confuse a Deaf child.
She is dependent on an interpreter and cannot participate spontaneously.
The Deaf child has to look at the teacher who is speaking, and then look at the interpreter for translation in Sign Language.
Having to look at so many places at once is intense and takes concentration.
questions.marker_instruction: Accept any TWO of the above or similar responses.

model_answers: The hearing learners are ignorant about the needs of a Deaf person.
This ignorance makes them appear to be inconsiderate of the Deaf child on the playground.
They show no willingness to include the Deaf child, as they stare at her instead of making her feel included.
questions.marker_instruction: Accept any TWO of the above or similar responses.

model_answers: The interpreter is not keeping up with the spoken language, there is no smooth simultaneous/parallel interpretation taking place.
The interpreter waits for the person who is talking, then starts to sign.
questions.marker_instruction: Give one mark for ONE of the above reasons. Give an additional mark for depth in the explanation.

questions.text: Signer's comment at the very end of 'MAINSTREAM'
model_answers: The signer's comment at the end of the poem is one of shock towards mainstream, shown by the signs 'MAINSTREAM THAT'.
The comment implies that mainstream education is ignorant of the needs of the Deaf for simultaneous interpreting.
Everyone is looking at her because she is different and not including her as a newcomer.
Mainstream is ignorant of the social needs of Deaf people.
questions.marker_instruction: Accept any THREE of the above or similar responses.

questions.text: 'ASA STANDS UP FOR HERSELF' by University of Stellenbosch

introduction: Asa has a good background when it comes to rules and values. Asa's parents have rules about her dating, and good values have also been instilled by the school.
Asa is innocent and wants to obey her parents' instructions.
Asa, by nature, shies away from conflict.
She lacks the foresight to see how a situation could endanger her personal wellbeing.

points: Mandisa tells Asa that she needs to put on more lipstick. Asa's NMFs reveal that she does not agree but reluctantly accepts. Asa does not want to confront her cousin.
Mandisa stops Asa from sending an SMS to her father. Asa feels uneasy but lacks courage to refuse.
Asa is torn between loyalty to her father's rules (meeting any boy she dates) and peer pressure from Mandisa.
Mandisa influences Asa to believe Kenzo is charming/wealthy despite community disapproval. Asa trusts Mandisa blindly.
Kenzo pays for the meal which makes Asa uncomfortable as the school taught her to pay for her own to avoid expectations.
Mandisa forces Asa to watch a movie alone with Kenzo. Asa is anxious as she does not know him and parents would not approve.
Asa is aware of movie age restrictions and that she won't understand without subtitles, creating inner conflict.
Kenzo acts like a gentleman but Asa cannot refuse him paying, creating conflict on how to handle the situation.
Asa shows discomfort when Kenzo touches her shoulder/breast/hip. He exploits her vulnerability and takes advantage of her innocence.
Asa cannot argue with Kenzo because she is Deaf and there is a communication barrier. She is conflicted about body privacy.
Asa questions her lack of good judgement and feels disgusted/regretful for being so gullible.
Her internal conflict is resolved when she realizes she cannot allow herself to be manipulated and decides to defend her personal rights.

answers.value: Before – Asa wants to message her father to tell her where she is going but Mandisa asks her not to.
After – Mandisa tells Asa that Kenzo is 21 years old, does drugs but is rich.

model_answers: The family wants to know who she is going out with and what kind of person it is.
Asa's father wants to know where she is going so he knows where to fetch her.
Kenzo looks cool by nodding his head when he arrives.
Kenzo is relaxed holding the steering wheel with one hand.
Asa's father would have known Kenzo would take advantage and not permitted the date.
If the father met Kenzo, he would have perceived him as too old and prevented the date.
She would not have experienced sexual harassment.
She would not have felt guilty for doing things her parents did not approve of.
questions.marker_instruction: Accept any THREE of the above or similar responses.

model_answers: Encouraging Asa to conform to her image (lipstick).
Influencing Asa to go against father's rules and not inform him of whereabouts.
Ignoring clear indications of Asa being uncomfortable.
Introducing Asa to a boy parents would not approve of.
Placing Asa in danger by introducing her to a boy involved in criminal activities.
questions.marker_instruction: Accept any THREE of the above or similar responses.

model_answers: Kenzo harasses Asa sexually (breast/hip). She communicates discomfort and tries to leave.
Kenzo forces her back. Asa screams for attention but nobody helps.
Kenzo tries to silence her with his hand over her mouth.
Asa bites his hand and escapes. The bathroom is a safe place where Kenzo cannot follow.
questions.marker_instruction: The depth of explanation must be considered when rewarding marks.

model_answers: Asa cries because she is disgusted by sexual harassment.
Asa reflects and questions herself for agreeing to be alone with Kenzo.
Asa deeply regrets allowing herself to be in this appalling situation.
Asa blames herself and criticises herself for being naïve.
Asa blames herself for allowing manipulation by Mandisa and Kenzo.
questions.marker_instruction: Accept any THREE of the above or similar responses.

model_answers: Submissive to Mandisa – agreed not to tell parents despite knowing it was wrong.
Weak-willed – agreed to date a 21-year-old while she is only 15.
Easily influenced – agreed to watch a movie despite age restrictions.
Inexperienced – did not realize being alone with Kenzo could endanger her wellbeing.
questions.marker_instruction: Accept any THREE of the above or similar responses.

questions.text: Asa's father as a significant person
model_answers: He brought her up to obey rules.
His advice (ignored) could have prevented the dangerous situation.
In moments of self-reflection, Asa thinks about his advice.
He was upset but immediately went to help his daughter.
He used an expensive Uber, showing he cares more about wellbeing than money.
questions.marker_instruction: Accept FOUR of the above or similar responses.

questions.text: 'TOGETHER WE'RE STRONG' by University of Stellenbosch

introduction: Ma Monikazi has strong intuitions that her daughter Nontsikelelo will be a freedom fighter and 'mother of the nation'.
The apartheid era was filled with violence, oppression, and constant conflicts between police and resistance fighters.

points: Violation of culture when forced to choose an English name at school; she values her traditional name but gives in for the sake of education.
Inner conflict due to being away from family; she misses them and is sorrowful.
Inner struggles as a nurse, wondering if siblings are hungry or in school while she cares for others.
Societal conflict: she wins a competition but is denied a scholarship due to age discrimination; she holds back tears bravely.
Forced to leave home for a far-away Catholic school to pursue education; scholarship conditions forced her to work during holidays, away from family.
Police raid: shouting at police for being rude and damaging her flowers; she replants them believing they will grow again.
Supporting and hiding her husband's secrets from the police.
Husband's 26-year imprisonment; she continues fighting for the dompas to be disbanded.
Imprisoned and released by the apartheid government several times.

answers.value: Before – Ntsiki attends school at age six and is forced to choose an English name.
After – She chooses the name Albertina and is later chosen as head girl.

model_answers: Ntsiki feels there is nothing wrong with her name.
She likes the name she has.
She does not understand why she has to get a new name.
She does not know what the English name means.
questions.marker_instruction: Accept any THREE of the above.

model_answers: Goal orientated; studies hard for tests to further high school education.
Sacrifices time with family and endures loneliness to complete education.
Trains to become a nurse to help people.
Questioning the reason for changing her name; standing up for herself.
Supporting husband by not disclosing secrets; being protective and defiant.
Voicing unhappiness at the police for their rudeness and trespassing.
Organising a march to the Union Building against unfair government treatment.
questions.marker_instruction: Accept any THREE of the above or similar responses.

model_answers: Loved and took care of siblings (washing clothes, cleaning, cooking).
Comforted baby brother until he laughed.
Sang mother's special song to her baby brother.
Always thought of family wellbeing while away.
Comforted sick babies in hospital by singing.
Always dreamed of having her own children.
questions.marker_instruction: Accept any TWO of the above.

questions.text: Reasons Albertina fell in love with Walter
model_answers: He was a clever man.
He was brave; she was attracted to his strong personality as a political fighter.
Shared vision of a free and just South Africa.
He was friendly and had a big smile.
questions.marker_instruction: Accept any TWO of the above.

model_answers: Inspired her to fight for a South Africa where her child could be free.
Caused her and husband to become involved in politics to oppose apartheid.
She protected her husband's secrets to help the fight for freedom.
questions.marker_instruction: Accept the above or similar responses.

model_answers: Supported her husband in a group that resisted and later negotiated with the government.
Became a freedom fighter herself, playing an active role in political change.
Organised the women's march in Pretoria against the dompas.
Combined efforts ended the apartheid government.
questions.marker_instruction: Accept any TWO of the above and the last point.

model_answers: Yes: Mother's foresight at birth ('mother of all blessings').
Yes: Strong-willed as a child, questioning authority.
Yes: Longed for and pursued a free/democratic SA for everyone.
Yes: Joined women's movement to march against pass laws.
Yes: Undying love for freedom proved true through hard work and jail time.
No: Unlikely response but well-motivated response should be credited.
questions.marker_instruction: Accept any similar responses. The depth of the argument must be considered.

questions.text: 'LIVING ON THE EDGE' by University of Stellenbosch
questions.topic: Peer insensitivity and ignorance towards Kim's circumstances

introduction: Kim is a Deaf university student dependent on her grandmother's pension and a bursary.
The loss of her grandmother has a huge impact on her financial, academic, and personal life.

points: Vernonique believes Kim can never be on the same social level; displays arrogant attitude and disbelief.
Tarone ignorantly comments on Kim forgetting a textbook, lacking empathy for her financial situation.
Tarone embarrasses Kim by asking why her mother does not give financial support despite being reminded of her plight.
Tarone is unsympathetic regarding Kim's absenteeism due to her grandmother's illness.
Tarone brags about his wealthy home/flat when Kim explains she must sell things to pay rent.
Lecturer tries to persuade Kim to talk, but does not fully understand the severity of her situation.
Classmates are cruel after grandmother's death; move away because she smells bad due to deteriorating hygiene.
Tarone and Veronique gossip and show disgust rather than finding out why she is struggling.
Veronique admits she and Tarone never supported Kim and dismisses her worth as a friend.
Kim's other friends are the ones who provided support.

conclusion: Kim fought two battles: poverty/destitution and peer insensitivity.
Wealthy peers like Tarone and Veronique do not understand her plight because they have only been exposed to wealth.
There is a need to develop personal courage to overcome challenges like prejudice and social inequality.

answers.value: Before - End of scene two. Veronique reprimands Tarone for asking about Kim's mother.
After - Beginning of scene 4 where Kim is called into the lecture's office.

model_answers: Veronique is annoyed with Tarone for asking why Kim's mother isn't helping.
She averts attention by asking how Kim's grandmother is doing.
questions.marker_instruction: Discuss in detail for full marks to be awarded.

model_answers: Grew up rich and never experienced poverty; snobbish and brags about his house.
Does not show sympathy or respect for those not on his financial/social level.
Does not understand circumstances different from his; cannot empathise.
Highlights the social inequality between Kim and Tarone.
questions.marker_instruction: Depth of the answer has to be considered.

model_answers: Sacrificed two weeks of class to care for her; studies were neglected.
Financial worry and stress of selling grandmother's things to support her.
Decline in appearance indicating depression.
Self-isolation and refusal of help.
questions.marker_instruction: Accept any THREE of the above or similar responses.

questions.text: Kim's changing appearance links to the plot
model_answers: Beginning: Neat/clean hair and clothes; indicates she is feeling okay and has a normal social life.
Middle (Rising action): Greasy hair, dark circles, sloppy posture; indicates lack of sleep due to burden and stress.
Middle (Falling action): Hygiene deteriorates, greasy hair; indicates neglect of physical/emotional care and depression.
End: Clean, light-coloured clothes and hair; indicates she is feeling better, confident, and able to care for herself.
questions.marker_instruction: Accept any THREE of the above or similar responses.

questions.text: Account for Kim's attitudes in extract
model_answers: Frustrated as she cannot see how counselling will help.
Angry because students with financial means are insensitive ('ALL FORGET').
Sarcastic about other students' expensive orders during group work.
Frustrated because wealthy students boast ('RICH PARTY').
questions.marker_instruction: Accept any THREE of the above or similar responses.

model_answers: To break the communication barrier by recognizing the need for an interpreter.
Adamant to share info on available psychological/grief services.
Explains that a social worker can provide vouchers for food/toiletries.
Shows compassion and willingness to accompany Kim to support services.
questions.marker_instruction: Accept any THREE of the above or similar responses.

model_answers: Kim approaches the university social worker for emotional distress services.
Received financial help in the form of vouchers for daily needs.
Managed to focus on studies and gained entry to exams.
Made supportive friends in Amy and her brother.
questions.marker_instruction: Accept any THREE of the above or any similar responses.

questions.text: Author's implied motives in creating drama
model_answers: Convey importance of compassion towards fellow students with challenges.
Educate viewer not to make assumptions about others' circumstances.
Create awareness of poverty, social inequality, and loss.
Create awareness of the benefits of empathy, care, love, and support.
Motivate respect, understanding, and uplifting of each other.
Alert people to break down communication barriers.
questions.marker_instruction: Accept any THREE of the above or similar responses. The depth of a single argument must be considered.
